Creator: ISO/IEC MPEG Audio Committee
Proprietary implementations (codecs): FAAC (encoding only), Nero Digital Audio, Apple CoreAudio (via QuickTime, iTunes or afconvert[2])
Open-source implementations (codecs): FAAD2 (decoding only), FFmpeg, Audiocogs[3] (decoding only), Fraunhofer FDK AAC
Uses (other than consumer audio): Digital TV service, Digital Radio, Internet streaming

Creator: Dolby Laboratories
Open-source implementations (codecs): FFmpeg, liba52 (decoding only), Aften (encoding only), libavc (2.0 channels max)
Uses (other than consumer audio): Theatrical movie presentation, Digital TV service & home-video (personal recorders, DVD, etc.)

Creator: Digital Voice Systems
Uses (other than consumer audio): Low bandwidth HF/VHF digital radio, VoIP trunking

Creator: 3GPP
Open-source implementations (codecs): FFmpeg (decoding only), FFmpeg with OpenCORE libraries,[7] Android[8]

Creator: 3GPP
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg (decoding only),[7] FFmpeg with VisualOn libraries, Android (decoding only),[8] opencore-amr for both encoding and decoding

Creator: APTX
Open-source implementations (codecs): Broadcast audio codecs: 2wcom systems, Systembase, APT, AVT, Harris Corporation, MAYAH, Prodys, Qbit
Uses (other than consumer audio): wireless headphones: iSkin, JayBird Gear, DTS discs for movies
Telephony app: Low latency Studio/transmitter link, Bluetooth A2DP stereo, digital wireless microphone

Creator: Sony Corp.
Open-source implementations (codecs): MiniDisc, Walkman, VAIO, Clie, PlayStation 3, PlayStation Portable, SDDS, SonicStage, SoundForge, RealPlayer, ConnectPlayer
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg (decoding only, ATRAC Advanced Lossless is only partially supported)

Creator: Broadcom
Music reproduction (consumer audio): Speech, VoIP, Low latency, voice recording

Creator: Xiph.Org Foundation, Jean-Marc Valin
Uses (other than consumer audio): libcelt, FFmpeg with libcelt library (decoding only)
Music reproduction (consumer audio): Speech, VoIP, Low latency, Studio/transmitter link, wireless audio

Creator: David Rowe
Music reproduction (consumer audio): Low bandwidth HF/VHF digital radio, VoIP trunking

Creator: Dolby Laboratories
Music reproduction (consumer audio): Theatrical movie presentation, digital TV service & home-video (personal recorders, DVD, etc.)

Creator: Xiph.Org Foundation, Josh Coalson
Uses (other than consumer audio): FLAC,[11] Flake[12] (encoding only), FFmpeg, FLACCL[13] (encoding only), Audiocogs[14] (decoding only)

Creator: ITU-T
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg, Ekiga, Asterisk (PBX) and almost any VoIP software

Creator: ITU-T (adopted directly from 3GPP)
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg (decoding only),[7] FFmpeg with VisualOn libraries, Android (decoding only)[8]

Creator: ITU-T
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg, Ekiga and other VoIP software

Creator: ETSI Special Mobile Group
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg (decoding only), FFmpeg with external library libgsm, Ekiga and other VoIP software

Creator: Global IP Solutions
Open-source implementations (codecs): Cisco IP Communicator,[19] old versions of Skype[20]
Uses (other than consumer audio): Ekiga, Asterisk (PBX) and other VoIP software, FFmpeg with libilbc library

Creator: ISO/IEC MPEG Audio Committee
Open-source implementations (codecs): various DVD software, video software, audio software

Creator: ISO/IEC MPEG Audio Committee
Open-source implementations (codecs): FhG, l3enc, MP3enc, (old implementations: Xing TOMPG, SCMPX)
Uses (other than consumer audio): LAME (encoding only), FFmpeg (decoding only), libmad (decoding only), Audiocogs[25] (decoding only), (old implementations: BladeEnc)

Creator: Xiph.Org Foundation, Internet Engineering Task Force
Music reproduction (consumer audio): Speech, VoIP, Low latency, Studio/transmitter link, wireless audio, voice recording, WebRTC

Creator: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone
Open-source implementations (codecs): Winamp with VQF plugin, NTT TwinVQ player/encoder, Yamaha SoundVQ player, Nero Media Player

Creator: Microsoft
Proprietary implementations (codecs): Free for licensees of the Windows operating system[41]
Open-source implementations (codecs): Windows Media Player, Windows Media Encoder
Uses (other than consumer audio): FFmpeg (decoding only for Pro, Lossless and Voice)
